description: This model follows Whitty et al.’s 7‑phase framework to characterize typical patterns and warning signs in romance scam conversations.

stages.name: Find the Dream Mate
stages.description: Initial scanning for potential victims; messages are friendly and vague with no explicit requests.
pattern_features: Shallow self‑introductions: 'I also live in City X'

stages.name: Contact via fake profile
stages.description: Start personalized outreach; uses flattery or feigned shared interests to lure the victim.
pattern_features: Feigning shared interests: 'I love X too'

stages.name: Grooming
stages.description: Engage in sustained emotional communication, expressing care and long‑term commitment to build trust.
pattern_features: Lengthy caring messages: 'I look forward to talking to you every day'

stages.name: The Sting
stages.description: Create dependency by revealing hardship or emotional pain as a form of manipulation.
pattern_features: Complaints of distress: 'I’ve been feeling so lonely/painful'
Urgent pleas: 'I don’t know who else to turn to'

stages.name: Continuation of the Scam
stages.description: Make the first monetary request, citing emergencies or investment opportunities.
pattern_features: Small monetary asks: 'Can you lend me $100?'
Crisis excuse: 'My medical bills/account is locked'

stages.name: Sexual Exploitation
stages.description: Solicit nude photos or sexual content, sometimes to leverage victims for blackmail.
pattern_features: Request for nudes: 'Send me a private photo'

stages.name: Re‑victimization
stages.description: After the initial scam, return with new lies to extract additional funds or restart the con.
pattern_features: Repeat requests: 'I still need help with that money'
